title: Kafre Images

body:
Introduction Introduction text: "Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit, sed do eiusmod tempor incididunt ut labore et dolore magna aliqua. Ut enim ad minim veniam, quis nostrud exercitation ullamco laboris nisi ut aliquip ex ea commodo consequat. Duis aute irure dolor in reprehenderit in voluptate velit esse cillum dolore eu fugiat nulla pariatur. Excepteur sint occaecat cupidatat non proident, sunt in culpa qui officia deserunt mollit anim id est laborum."
Contents Main Observations Overview and Comparison of faces Pictures and Tables All Observations Acknowledgements Main Observations Construction Consistency The construction of the casing stones still remaining is, in many ways, much more consistent than we might expect from only the second ever attempt at building such a large structure. These casing stones are still here 4500 years later, and the majority of courses are straight, even and well fitted.
With that said: there are also significant consistency issues with what we can see of the North Face, and to some extent the South Face. The East Face, in contrast, is much neater. The North Face has significant upwards bulging of the center of its stone courses, and multiple sections of "wobbly" masonry above this area, which is likely due to the difficulty of juggling between a desire for straight, even courses and needing to correct for the earlier bulging issues. The South Face is straight on average, but also contains several "wobbly" masonry courses, mostly centered around individual stones which are taller or shorter than they should be.
North Face South Face Coloured by vertical offset from course Coloured by vertical offset from course Coloured by relative height to course Coloured by relative height to course Tall and short stones, and the not-quite-straight masonry surround them Tall and short stones, and the not-quite-straight masonry surround them The height of the casing stones is maintained within a course around the faces of the pyramid (i.e. from north to east to south), and the statistical distribution of the stones within each of these unified courses appears to be consistent. This suggests a singular source and quarrying directive supplying each unified course. Note how the highlighted courses all have lower average width, across all three faces. They are surrounded by courses above and below with higher average width. Bulging in the North Face There is very visable upwards deflection (bulging) of the courses on the North Face. By examining the expected vertical position of courses based on the height of casing stones, it is clear that the corners of the courses are at the correct position, and the centre is located higher up than it should be. This construction issue occured below the current level of the casing stones, and is not present on the other faces (I also visually inspected photos of the West Face and couldn't see any). Stones coloured by their course. Some white and red horizontal lines for comparison of 'straightness'.
Blue=North, Green=East, Red=South. Lighter lines are measure of absolute deflection of a single course (vertical offset between center and edges of a course), darker lines of cumulative deflection (how much taller/shorter the center stones of a course are compared to the edge stones).
The above graph charts the deflection of the courses numerically. Note that: below course 75 on the North Face, the courses are missing the outside casing stones. This obscurs the singular course deflection measurement (lighter lines) which is measured as the different in vertical position between the edges and the center of the course. The cumulative deflection measurement is also affected, however the actual numbers can be estimated and the difference is minimal.
The cumulative deflection series for East and South also show a small amount of deflection (darker), however comparison with the absolute deflection (lighter) suggests that this is the result of some small systematic error which has accumulated.
Blue=North, Yellow=East, Red=South. Local deflection causes by each individual course. NOTE WHEN DOING THIS CHART, SWAWP THE EAST SOUTH COLOURS TO MATCH EARLIER CHART
By observing the contribution to the total deflection from each course, we can see that for the entirety of the height of casing stones still remaining, the North Face builders were trying to correct for the positive vertical deflection which must have originated further down the pyramid.
Joining, or fitting, stones https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=43V9RTpnxbk

Image scaling and pyramid dimensions Internal Dimensions Pyramid Face Dimensions Internal, vertical pyramid dimensions. A vertical slice down the center of the pyramid. External, sloping pyramid dimensions. The entirety of a single face. The (original) height of the pyramid was 143.5m. The angle between the face and the horizontal is approximately 53.15degrees, with different sources providing slightly different exact numbers. If you calculate the length along the centreline of a face of the pyramid, up to the apex, you get 179.45m (from the base length and the vertical height). The ratio of these two lengths is 1:1.25, or 0.8:1. This seems like a good, simple ratio (4 to 5) for the pyramid builders to use, so I used this ratio (approx. 53.13degrees) when scaling the image data I had.
I used the three tall consecutive courses (courses 71-73) of casing stones as an achor for scaling the image. From visual inspection, the casing stones make up the top 28-30% of the pyramid height, and the three tall courses occur approximately 75% down the casing stones. This puts the three tall courses approx. 39m below the apex, as measured along the angled face, and approx. 31.2m vertically below the apex. The width of the casing stone courses at this point is approx. 46.9m. Note that, the effective angle of the edge of the face itself, when measured in the plane of the face, is 59 degrees.

Tabulated Statistics Introduction text: "Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit, sed do eiusmod tempor incididunt ut labore et dolore magna aliqua. All Observations Observations Contents General Construction Consistency Bulging in the North Face Similarity in stone widths across faces The three large courses Joining or fitting stones Chains of offset stones Corner Pattern Alternating corner pattern Change in the corner pattern Vertical Edge Angles Angles of stone’s vertical edges Angles on corner stones Vertical edge angle distribution by size of stone Stats By Course Distribution of course heights Distribution of stone width by course Relationship between width of stone and height of course Height variation of stones within a course Course width by height up the pyramid Distribution of breaks in courses Vertical offset of stones relative to their course Vertical deflection of courses Stats by Stone Stone stats by position along course Big vs small stones Wide vs narrow stones Upper vs lower stones Right vs left half stones Corner stones Wide vs narrow corner stones Contribution of “bad” stones Width vs height Stats by height Stats by width Stats by size Alignment of central stones 1. Construction Consistency INSERT SIDE BY SIDE IMAGES OF relative width?
Construction appears much more consistent near the apex of the pyramid, and below course 55. The construction near to the corners of the pyramid is much more uniform throughout, due to the builders utilising a consistent, repeating pattern in the stonework. Since the top of the pyramid has a higher proportion of its width taken up by these "edge patterns", it appears more uniform.
In the below chart, the courses have stones with a more uniform average width below course 55. Courses 30 - 55 appear to have many taller and wider courses.
INSERT CHART OF Avg Stone Width Within Course by Course,
2. Bulging in the North Face INSERT HEIGHT REALTIVE TO COURSE NORTH FACE
At some point in construction, the center of the north-face courses began to bulge upwards, become higher than the edges of the course. There appears to have been a concerted effort to fix this issue, by using shorter blocks for the centers of the course. This effort began below the currently existing courses (below 89), and corrected by roughly 2.7cm per course between courses 75 and 50, and by roughly 1.09cm per course between courses 50 and 10. Above course 10 the issue is resolved.
CHART OF DEFLECTION AND CUMULTIVE DEFLECTION BY COURSE
3. Similarity in stone widths across faces There is a weak correlation between the average widths of casing stones which are on the same course, but different faces of the pyramid. Mostly, it is noticeable that courses within a face with narrow or wide stones, tend to maintain this pattern around the other faces. Note courses 23, 47 and 52 all have much narrower stones than their adjacent courses.
CHART OF AVG WIDTH BY COURSE
4. The three large courses INSERT ALL THREE PICTURES OF HEIGHT RELATIVE TO AVG HEIGHT, SIDE BY SIDE
There are three visually distinctive courses, which all have very tall stones compared to the average. These correspond to 71-73, and are an interesting feature of the casing stones. Perhaps the builders encountered a very large seam of high quality limestone during their quarrying, and wished to take advantage of it.
5. Joining or fitting stones INSERT ALL THREE PICTURES OF width RELATIVE TO AVG width within course, SIDE BY SIDE
There appears to be linear patterns of small stones (as others have noted, REF), which segment the pyramid faces into sections. This may well be evidence of sections of the face being the duty of seperate work crews, and these smaller stones were use to bridge or join the gap between the more normal stones laid by the two seperate work crews.
INSERT 2, side by side, images of north face width relCourse, and an annotated image drawing lines of stones
Many of these "fitting" stones have angled vertical edges, which would allow them to be maneuvered into place from above. The construction of this angled edge, would likely involve taken one of the "normal" blocks, and cutting it at an angle into two trapezoids. The smaller trapezoid can then be shaved down to the exact size needed to fit the gap, and dropped into place from above.
INSERT several, side by side, images of individual "fitting" stones
6. Chains of offset stones INSERT SIDE BY SIDE EXAMPLES OF CHAINS OF STONES
There appear to be "chains" of stones, whereby each stone in the chain is offset from the previous by a set amount, and the size of the stones in the chain are all very similar. The number of these occuring mean these aren't random chance, and are somehow related to the building technique.
Some of these chains are offset at an angle similar to the angle of the edge of the face, but some are in the opposite direction.
It is possible, that multiple courses were placed simultaneously, and these chains of stones were the first ones placed amidst otherwise empty courses. Chains of stones in a consistent, overlapping pattern, and with the correct course height, could be useful as an anchor of stability within the otherwise more peicemeal construction.
7. Alternating corner pattern INSERT TWO zoomed in images of the pattern, one with 1+1 to overlap, 1 with 1+2 to overlap
The edges of each course follow a distinctive alternating pattern. A wide corner stone is then followed above by a narrower corner stone, and a second (and sometimes third) stone which extends to overlap the first stone.
There are also hints of an alternating taller to shorter to taller pattern in the corner stones.
INSERT IMAGE Height rel to course (EAST?) zoomed in on corner area exibiting this
8. Change in the corner pattern INSERT IMAGE OF THE TRANSITION
Around course 33, there is a shift in the width of the corner stones. Both wide and narrow corner stones are wider on average below course 33, and the wide corner stones in particular are significantly wider.
INSERT MINI TABLE WITH SOME STATS FROM WIDE LOWER CORNER VS WIDER UPPER CORNER
9. Angles of stone’s vertical edges Overall, left edges are slightly clockwise rotated, and right edges are slightly anti-clockwise rotated, which makes sense due to the strongly angled edges of the cornerstones. Without the cornerstones in the analysis, edge angles average out to vertical. When considering stones on the left half of the face, vs those on the right, it can be seen that edge angles are slightly more likely to be angled in the same direction as the nearest edge of the face.
INSERT MINI TABLE WITH STATS
10. Angles on corner stones Both left and right corners, have an average other edge angle of 1.75degrees. This average "other edge angle" leans towards the same side as the pyramid edge. This is in comparison to an average angle of 1.5degrees on non-corner stones.
INSERT MINI TABLE
11. Vertical edge angle distribution by size of stone Both large and small stones, have a similar distribution of edge angles, with both groups averaging out to a near zero edge angle (when excluding corner stones).
INSERT MINI TABLE
12. Distribution of course heights Course height tends to decrease up the pyramid, and there seems to be a clear minimum course height, which also decreases up the pyramid.
INSERT CHART OF COURSE HEIGHT VS COURSE, WITH DRAWN ON EXTRA LINES FOR MIN AND TRENDLINE
13. Distribution of stone width by course Stone width appears un-correlated with course number, however below course 55, the width is much more consistant from course to course. Between course 50 - 55, there are many courses with higher average width. There also appears to be some clustering of higher widths (i.e. high width adjacent course predicts higher avg stone width in this course).
INSERT CHART OF COURSE AVG STONE WIDTH BY COURSE
14. Relationship between width of stone and height of course Slight negative correlation between height of course and avg. width of stone within that course. If courses 40-50 are removed there is probably no correlation, as courses 40-50 have many short courses with wide stones.
INSERT CHART OF "Stone Width vs Height within Course"
15. Height variation of stones within a course INSERT 3 IMAGES SIDE BY SIDE OF RELATIVE HEIGHT TO COURSE
Not much of any obious pattern. The random variation of stone heights from what they should be is larger than the average "correction" done on the north face. It is clear on the north face that there are more taller than average stones near the edges of the course. And possibly also more shorter stones within the central part of the course.
16. Course width by height up the pyramid INSERT CHART OF COURSE WIDTH VS DIST FROM APEX
A very consistent linear correlation. Only slightly noisy near the top and near the bottom, due to missing stones
17. Distribution of breaks in courses INSERT CHART OF BREAKS
More gaps lower down the pyramid, which is to be expected sense since there are more stones to be missing. Major issues around course 71-74
18. Vertical offset of stones relative to their course INSERT 3 SIDE BY SIDE IMAGES
Introduction text: "Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit, sed do eiusmod tempor incididunt ut labore et dolore magna aliqua. Ut enim ad minim veniam, quis nostrud exercitation ullamco laboris nisi ut aliquip ex ea commodo consequat. Duis aute irure dolor in reprehenderit in voluptate velit esse cillum dolore eu fugiat nulla pariatur. Excepteur sint occaecat cupidatat non proident, sunt in culpa qui officia deserunt mollit anim id est laborum."
INSERT LARGE NORTH FACE IMAGE
19. Vertical deflection of courses INSERT CHART CUMULATIVE DEFLECTION
Slightly noisy distribution centered around 0 for the east and south faces. The north face has more shorter stones in the centre (than taller ones), resulting in a significant, non-zero cumulative deflection. This appears to be an intentional effort to correct the "bulging" issue. The dropoff in "Deflection vs edges" after course 75 is due to the edges of those courses being missing.
INSERT CHART OF local deflection of center vs edge
20. Stone stats by position along course Most statistics do not deviate from the overall distribution. Edge angle has an interesting pattern, notably more edges are aligned towards the pyramid edge closest to them.
INSERT CHART OF EDGE ANGLE BY FRACTION ALONG COURSE
21. Big vs small stones Statistic Comparison Fraction fill Similar Distance down pyramid Bigger is further down Distribution along course Similar Edge angles Similar Width Bigger stones are significantly narrower (approx 80cm vs 110cm) 22. Wide vs narrow stones Statistic Comparison Fraction fill Similar Distance down pyramid Similar Distribution along course Similar Edge angles Similar, but narrower stones have a slightly higher absolute edge angle (2.1deg vs 1.9deg) Height Narrower stones are very slightly taller 23. Upper vs lower stones Statistic Comparison Fraction fill Similar Distance down pyramid Bigger is further down Distribution along course Similar Edge angles Lower stones have slightly more angled edges (abs. edge angle of 2.25deg vs 1.7deg) Height Lower stones are taller Width Lower stones are slightly narrower Size Lower stones are significantly bigger 24. Right vs left half stones left stones are very slightly larger, due to them being slightly wider on average. Right stones have left+right edge angles approx 1.5deg anti-clockwise, left stones have left+right edge angles approx 1.5deg clockwise
Statistic Comparison Fraction fill Similar Edge angles ~1.2degrees clockwise for left stones and anti-clockwise for right stones Height Similar Width Left stones are slightly wider 25. Corner stones Corner stones are on average: significantly shorter and wider. Note that we are missing some of the corners near the bottom, where the courses are taller.
INSERT STATS MINI TABLE
26. Wide vs narrow corner stones Overall, wide corners are slightly further down on average and wide corners are very slightly taller on average.
27. Contribution of “bad” stones Since only 5 stones were identified as "bad" with the method I used, excluding them from the statistics had little effect.
28. Width vs height Slight negative correlation between width and height of casing stones. i.e. if a stone is wider, it is likely to also be slightly shorter. This may be because larger stones are harder to transport. It is particularly noticeable that almost all of the larger stones are only up to around average height, and not taller.
INSERT CHART WITH TRENDLINE HERE
29. Stats by height Very wide stones tend to be significantly shorter.
30. Stats by width By considering width vs fraction along course, can see that wide stones are often the first or last stones in a course.
31. Stats by size INSERT IMAGE OF SIZE REL ALL , 3 SIDE BY SIDE
The biggest stones seem less likely to occur near the center of the course.
INSERT CHART
32. Alignment of central stones The "central stones" are stones which span the vertical centreline of the pyramid.
Statistic Comparison Fraction fill Similar Edge angles Much more vertical edge angles than average, (approx. 1deg average angle vs 2deg) Width Slightly wider than average Size Slightly smaller than average Offset from centreline Approximately 5cm right on average 33. Gaps at top of South Face The gaps between stones at the top of the South Face, are due to stones shifting to the left of where they should be. This was possibly caused by an earthquake, or by whoever tumbled the missing top stones down the pyramid. Top of the South Face. White lines indicate the expected pyramid outline. Note how the top courses are shifted left outside the outline, and moreso near the top.
Acknowledgements Desmos for triangle diagrams, "History for Granite" youtube channel, etc. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=43V9RTpnxbk
https://www.flickr.com/photos/amthomson/albums/72157667783909188/with/26579978777/ Aidan McRae Thomson
